summary_md: This round settled the nowhere‑density half of the conjecture: for any unrooted property P the rooted set S_P is saturated, and nowhere‑density is root‑invariant. Key ingredients: if S is saturated then cl(S) and Int(cl(S)) are saturated (proved by transporting large matching balls and re‑rooting), and an equivalent root‑free cylinder criterion: S_P is nowhere dense iff every rooted r‑ball F admits an extension F' whose cylinder is disjoint from S_P. The meagre half was reduced to an Amb_k strategy: for a nowhere‑dense N, Sat_k(N) is covered by countably many homeomorphic images of N plus an ambiguity set Amb_k; the plan is to make each Amb_k meagre using degree‑preserving marker (boundary‑hub / beacon) gadgets (separate treatments for Δ≤D and Δ=D, with D=2 exceptional). Also: for D≥3, Br_≤k (bridge within distance ≤k) is nowhere dense, so “has a 2‑way infinite bridge” is meagre but dense. Caveats: forget‑the‑root quotient need not be open; correct Theorem 4 (needs bridgelessness). Citations: Current Proofs; papers/paper1.txt
one_line_summary: Nowhere density of S_P is root‑invariant; meagre case reduced to Amb_k + markers
highlights: If S is saturated then cl(S) and Int(cl(S)) are saturated (via re‑rooting large balls).
Root‑free cylinder criterion: S_P nowhere dense ⇔ every r‑ball F has an extension F' with C(F')∩S_P=∅; hence ND is root‑independent.
The forget‑the‑root quotient map need not be open, so naive quotient arguments for meagreness fail.
Meagre problem reduced to Amb_k: Sat_k(N) is ⋃(homeomorphic images of N) ∪ Amb_k, so it suffices to show Amb_k is meagre.
A boundary‑hub/beacon construction (Δ≤D and Δ=D cases) is sketched to break local symmetries and eliminate Amb_k; D=2 is exceptional.
For D≥3, Br_≤k (bridge within distance ≤k) is nowhere dense, so “2‑way infinite bridge” is meagre but dense (hence not ND).
next_questions: Prove Amb_k is meagre by constructing explicit degree‑preserving marker/port gadgets (treat Δ≤D, Δ=D; handle D=2).
Either build a Borel/continuous selector on a comeagre domain of uniquely marked roots or produce a counterexample to full meagre root‑invariance.
Correct and rework Theorem 4 (state and prove the right flow claim, e.g. add bridgelessness and fix finite‑satisfiability step).
